story:
Our friend, Sam, recently told us that a close family member has been diagnosed with cancer. “We’re so sorry!”, “Not again!” and “Let me know what I can do to help” were our responses when we heard. But what can we do to help? Covid19 and social distancing rules means that the normal support and distractions with coffee dates for Sam and play dates for children isn’t possible. 

With social support limited and professional support hugely changed we felt we couldn’t just sit and wait for Sam to ask us for help. We plan to show our support by literally walking the extra mile whilst raising money for Macmillan: the people who we know will support this family who is again affected by cancer.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
This November, I will be running 100km (62 miles) in memory of my Dad and to raise money for the British Heart Foundation, a Charity that is very close to my heart.

Sadly, nothing could ever have prepared my family and me for such a sudden, devastating loss on Wednesday 12th November 2014. There are no words to explain the inability to say goodbye to a loved one nor the lasting effect that this has. I know that there are so many families that have gone through or are going through the same heartache, loss and grief. Seven million people in the UK live with heart and circulatory diseases and these diseases are responsible for more than a quarter of all deaths. Due to Covid-19, the funding for new research has been halved.

Our remarkable NHS Staff continue to work tirelessly and at this time, the British Heart Foundation need our help more than ever. It is my aim to raise awareness of cardiac disease and to contribute towards their research. Your support and donations are so greatly appreciated.

There isn't a day that goes by when I don't think about what an incredibly special person my Dad was. He truly inspired me with his zest for life and adventure, his kind and generous soul and the love and care that he showed to all. He did so much for local charities and fully supported and appreciated the life changing work that the British Heart Foundation do.

With any challenge, goal or ambition, my Dad would always say, “GO FOR IT!” so, I am! Heels off, trainers on and with the vision of British Heart Foundation in mind, “let’s beat heartbreak forever!”

Thank you all so much for your kindness, generosity and support. 💖

story:
Thank you for taking the time visit our Just Giving page. 

We have both decided to take on the challenge in September 2021, to trek to Everest Base Camp with Swansea University . We have decided to do this  once  in a lifetime opportunity, to physically and mentally challenge ourselves while raising money and awareness for the charity, Marie Curie, which is very close to our hearts. We are flying from London to Kathmandu, Nepal’s vibrant capital, where we will then fly to Lukla on a twin engined plane. From here we will start our trek into the heart of the Nepali Himalaya, we will trek for 11 days, for several hours each day, through the Himalayan peaks reaching a significant altitude (5,545m above sea level)  eventually reaching  Everest Base Camp. We will be documenting our whole training journey and our trek, to take you along with us. 

Cancer is something which has affected the majority of us, whether through our own suffering or seeing a loved one suffer. By 2040, the number of new cancer cases per year is expected to rise to 29.5 million and the number of cancer-related deaths to 16.4 million, which are figures unbearable to think about. I think you can all agree with us that cancer is the most cruel and unbearable disease for both those suffering and those watching others suffer. It has taken away many of our loved ones when it simply wasn’t time for them to go. 

We will be grateful for any support you can give us, even if you can only spare a pound. We are hoping over the next 12 months to achieve a target of £6,000 for the amazing charity Marie Curie who support those that are living with a terminal illness daily. They are there through all aspects of dying, death and bereavement – and to fight for a society where everyone gets to lead the best life they can, right to the end. We understand this is a very difficult time for many , especially with the global pandemic we are all experiencing. Even if you can’t spare any money we would love you to support and come along on this adventure with us. 

Many thanks, 

Ross & Beth x

Marie Curie is the UK'S leading charity for those with terminal illnesses, providing hands-on care, emotional support and round the clock care for those nearing the end of life, ensuring that patients, their families and their friends receive the best end of life care. Having experienced the effects that illness has had on my family and friends, this challenge and its cause has spoken to me in particular. Since i have completed challenges prior such as my DofE and volunteering projects abroad, i have decided to take on my first challenge in uni- one that is doing amazing work for a cause that is often overlooked by many. story:
I have always loved the South West Coast - hiking, swimming, camping and would like the challenge of walking and wild camping in the Winter. The route is 630 miles and I hope to make it in 6 weeks.  I would like to support the RNLI because I have seen how ferocious the sea can be and fully appreciate the bravery of the men and women of the RNLI who risk their lives to make the coast line safe for the rest of us. 
Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place. Thank you.

story: Having endured severe vertigo for 3 years resulting in extreme mental and physical trauma, I sympathise with people suffering a living hell. This summer I regained the ability to swim, not sink. I plan to continue swimming at least once a week until my 76th birthday on 22/02/21 Most important is the reason - to help in a small way alleviate the effects of 5+ years of war - bombing, landmines, destruction of homes, plus acute malnutrition, cholera, lack of water and sanitation. Covid 19 has compounded the dire situation, affecting 80% of the population, including more than 12 million children. Health workers and teachers are often not paid and have scant equipment, but still continue the struggle.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
charity.registrationNumber: 288701 (England and Wales) and SC039479 (Scotland)
story:
Imagine trying to keep yourself and your family safe from Coronavirus without having access to clean water to wash your hands!! That is the reality for countless families across the world and why WaterAid is working harder than ever to achieve their mission of getting clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Taking part in this 10k is a huge personal challenge for me as it was exactly a year ago that I attempted my first few steps running after giving birth and will be the furthest I have run in well over 2 years. Due to a complicated birth and recovery I really thought running could be over for me, I did not think a year later I would be challenging myself to this! 

In addition to this; with clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.
